articles.title: Engineers just created a “phonon laser” that could shrink your next smartphone
articles.summary: Engineers have created a device that generates incredibly tiny, earthquake-like vibrations on a microchip—and it could transform future electronics. Using a new kind of “phonon laser,” the team can produce ultra-fast surface waves that already play a hidden role in smartphones, GPS systems, and wireless tech. Unlike today’s bulky setups, this single-chip device could deliver far higher performance using less power, opening the door to smaller, faster, and more efficient phones and wireless devices.
articles.content:
Engineers have taken a major step toward producing the smallest earthquakes ever created, shrinking seismic-style vibrations down to the scale of a microchip.

The breakthrough centers on a device called a surface acoustic wave phonon laser. The technology could eventually enable more advanced chips for smartphones and other wireless electronics, helping make them smaller, faster, and more energy efficient.

The research was led by Matt Eichenfield, an incoming faculty member at the University of Colorado Boulder, along with scientists from the University of Arizona and Sandia National Laboratories. Their findings were published Jan. 14 in the journal Nature.

What Are Surface Acoustic Waves?

The new device relies on surface acoustic waves, commonly known as SAWs. These waves behave somewhat like sound waves, but instead of traveling through the air or deep inside a material, they move only along its surface.

Large earthquakes naturally produce powerful surface acoustic waves that ripple across the Earth's crust, shaking buildings and causing damage. On a much smaller scale, SAWs are already essential to modern technology.

"SAWs devices are critical to the many of the world's most important technologies," said Eichenfield, senior author of the new study and Gustafson Endowed Chair in Quantum Engineering at CU Boulder. "They're in all modern cell phones, key fobs, garage door openers, most GPS receivers, many radar systems and more."

How SAWs Already Power Smartphones

Inside a smartphone, SAWs function as highly precise filters. Radio signals arriving from a cell tower are first converted into tiny mechanical vibrations. This allows chips to separate useful signals from interference and background noise. The cleaned vibrations are then converted back into radio waves.

In this study, Eichenfield and his colleagues introduced a new way to generate these surface waves using what they call a phonon laser. Unlike a typical laser pointer that emits light, this device produces controlled vibrations.

"Think of it almost like the waves from an earthquake, only on the surface of a small chip," said Alexander Wendt, a graduate student at the University of Arizona and lead author of the study.

Most existing SAW systems require two separate chips and an external power source. The new design combines everything into a single chip and could operate using just a battery while reaching much higher frequencies.

A Laser Built for Vibrations

To understand the new device, it helps to start with how conventional lasers work.

Many everyday lasers are diode lasers, which create light by bouncing it between two tiny mirrors on a semiconductor chip. As the light reflects back and forth, it interacts with atoms energized by an electric current. Those atoms release additional light, strengthening the beam.

"Diode lasers are the cornerstone of most optical technologies because they can be operated with just a battery or simple voltage source, rather than needing more light to create the laser like a lot of previous kinds of lasers," Eichenfield said. "We wanted to make an analog of that kind of laser but for SAWs."

To achieve this, the team built a bar-shaped device about half a millimeter long.

A Stack of Specialized Materials

The device consists of several layered materials. At its base is silicon, the same material used in most computer chips. Above that sits a thin layer of lithium niobate, a piezoelectric material. When lithium niobate vibrates, it produces oscillating electric fields, and those electric fields can also trigger vibrations.

The final layer is an extremely thin sheet of indium gallium arsenide. This material has unusual electronic properties and can accelerate electrons to very high speeds even under weak electric fields.

Together, these layers allow vibrations traveling along the lithium niobate surface to interact directly with fast-moving electrons in the indium gallium arsenide.

Making Waves Build Like a Laser

The researchers describe the device as working similarly to a wave pool.

When electric current flows through the indium gallium arsenide, surface waves form in the lithium niobate layer. These waves travel forward, strike a reflector, and then move backward, much like light reflecting between mirrors in a laser. Each forward pass strengthens the wave, while each backward pass weakens it.

"It loses almost 99% of its power when it's moving backward, so we designed it to get a substantial amount of gain moving forward to beat that," Wendt said.

After repeated passes, the vibrations grow strong enough that a portion escapes from one side of the device, similar to how laser light eventually exits its cavity.

Faster Waves, Smaller Devices

Using this approach, the team generated surface acoustic waves vibrating at about 1 gigahertz, meaning billions of oscillations per second. The researchers believe the same design could be pushed into tens or even hundreds of gigahertz.

Traditional SAW devices typically max out at around 4 gigahertz, making the new system far faster.

Eichenfield said the advance could lead to wireless devices that are smaller, more powerful, and more energy efficient.

In today's smartphones, multiple chips repeatedly convert radio waves into SAWs and back again whenever users send messages, make calls, or browse the internet. The researchers aim to simplify that process by creating a single chip that handles all of the signal processing using surface acoustic waves.

"This phonon laser was the last domino standing that we needed to knock down," Eichenfield said. "Now we can literally make every component that you need for a radio on one chip using the same kind of technology."
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant technological breakthrough in creating a phonon laser that can generate ultra-fast surface acoustic waves on a single microchip. This innovation promises to make smartphones and wireless devices smaller, faster, and more energy efficient, which has broad and meaningful implications for the general public. The article provides detailed context about the technology, its current applications, and its potential impact, fulfilling all criteria for inspiring good news.
articles.personality_title: New phonon laser could make smartphones smaller and faster
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Engineers have been working to improve how smartphones and wireless devices handle signals. Right now, these devices use special tiny vibrations called surface acoustic waves (SAWs) to help process radio signals, but the technology involves multiple chips and uses a fair amount of power.

**What happened** – A team of scientists led by Matt Eichenfield created a new kind of device called a phonon laser that produces these vibrations on just one microchip. This device uses layers of special materials to generate very fast surface waves, similar to tiny earthquakes on the chip’s surface. Their work was published in the journal Nature on January 14.

**Impact** – This new phonon laser can create waves vibrating billions of times per second—much faster than current devices. Because it combines all parts into one chip and uses less power, it could lead to smartphones and other wireless devices that are smaller, faster, and more energy efficient. This means better performance without bigger batteries or bulkier designs.

**What's next step** – The researchers plan to improve the technology to reach even higher speeds and include all radio signal processing on one chip. If successful, future phones might use this phonon laser chip to handle calls, messages, and internet signals more efficiently.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Scientists developed a tiny phonon laser that could shrink and speed up smartphones by creating ultra-fast vibrations on a single chip.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un nouveau laser phonon pourrait rendre les smartphones plus petits et plus rapides
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les ingénieurs cherchent à améliorer la manière dont les smartphones et les appareils sans fil traitent les signaux. Actuellement, ces appareils utilisent de petites vibrations appelées ondes acoustiques de surface (OAS) pour gérer les signaux radio, mais la technologie nécessite plusieurs puces et consomme beaucoup d’énergie.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Une équipe dirigée par Matt Eichenfield a créé un nouveau type de dispositif appelé laser phonon qui produit ces vibrations sur une seule puce. Ce dispositif utilise plusieurs couches de matériaux spéciaux pour générer des ondes très rapides, semblables à de mini tremblements de terre à la surface de la puce. Leur travail a été publié dans la revue Nature le 14 janvier.

**Impact** – Ce nouveau laser phonon peut créer des ondes qui vibrent des milliards de fois par seconde, bien plus vite que les dispositifs actuels. Comme il regroupe toutes les parties en une seule puce et consomme moins d’énergie, il pourrait rendre les smartphones et autres appareils sans fil plus petits, plus rapides et plus économes. Cela signifie de meilleures performances sans batteries plus grosses ni appareils plus encombrants.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs prévoient d’améliorer la technologie pour atteindre des vitesses encore plus élevées et intégrer tout le traitement des signaux radio sur une seule puce. Si cela réussit, les futurs téléphones pourraient utiliser cette puce laser phonon pour gérer appels, messages et internet de façon plus efficace.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Des scientifiques ont développé un petit laser phonon capable de réduire la taille des smartphones et d’accélérer leur fonctionnement en créant des vibrations ultra-rapides sur une seule puce.
articles.personality_title_es: Un nuevo láser de fonones podría hacer los smartphones más pequeños y rápidos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los ingenieros han estado trabajando para mejorar cómo los smartphones y dispositivos inalámbricos procesan las señales. Actualmente, estos dispositivos usan pequeñas vibraciones llamadas ondas acústicas superficiales (OAS) para manejar señales de radio, pero la tecnología requiere varios chips y consume bastante energía.

**Qué pasó** – Un equipo liderado por Matt Eichenfield creó un nuevo tipo de dispositivo llamado láser de fonones que produce estas vibraciones en un solo microchip. Este dispositivo usa capas de materiales especiales para generar ondas muy rápidas, similares a pequeños terremotos en la superficie del chip. Su trabajo fue publicado en la revista Nature el 14 de enero.

**Impacto** – Este nuevo láser de fonones puede crear ondas que vibran miles de millones de veces por segundo, mucho más rápido que los dispositivos actuales. Al combinar todas las partes en un solo chip y usar menos energía, podría hacer que los smartphones y otros dispositivos inalámbricos sean más pequeños, rápidos y eficientes. Esto significa mejor rendimiento sin baterías más grandes ni dispositivos voluminosos.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores planean mejorar la tecnología para alcanzar velocidades aún mayores e integrar todo el procesamiento de señales de radio en un solo chip. Si tienen éxito, los futuros teléfonos podrían usar este chip láser de fonones para manejar llamadas, mensajes e internet de manera más eficiente.

**Resumen en una frase** – Científicos desarrollaron un pequeño láser de fonones que podría reducir el tamaño y acelerar los smartphones creando vibraciones ultrarrápidas en un solo chip.

articles.title: PhD students’ taste for risk mirrors their supervisors’
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 15 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00160-4Learned risk-taking behaviours can persist for years after leaving the lab — and even after taking on a new research topic.
articles.content:
Students are more likely to show risk-taking behaviour if their supervisors have a tendency for risky projects. Credit: Getty

A researchers’ propensity for risky projects is passed down to their doctoral students — and stays with trainees after they leave the laboratory, according to an analysis1 of thousands of current and former PhD students and their mentors.

Science involves taking risks, and some of the most impactful discoveries require taking big bets. However, scientists and policymakers have raised concerns that the current academic system’s emphasis on short-term outcomes encourages researchers to play it safe. Studies have shown, for example, that risky research is less likely to be funded2,3. Anders Broström, an economist studying science policy at the University of Gothenburg in Sweden, and his colleagues decided to examine the role of doctoral education in shaping risk-related behaviour — an area that Broström says has been largely overlooked.

“We often focus on thinking about how we can change the funding systems to make it more likely for people to take risks, but that’s not the only lever we have,” says Chiara Franzoni, an economist at the Polytechnic University of Milan in Italy. This study is “refreshing” because “we’ve discussed policy interventions a lot, but we haven’t discussed training”, she adds.

Leaps into the unknown

Broström and his colleagues first looked at the effect of supervision on current students. They received responses to a survey designed to measure risk-taking from 1,223 PhD students enrolled in medical-science programmes at seven universities in Sweden. Participants were asked, for example, to report how likely they were to take part in a safe project — defined as one that would guarantee publication in a mid-ranking journal — compared with a risky project, which was less likely to succeed but more likely to end up in a high-ranking publication.

The researchers also examined the publication history of the students and their supervisors. To calculate the risk level involved in a particular study, they used a machine-learning algorithm that predicted the likelihood of ideas from other studies being successfully combined (determined by how often pairs of citations appeared together in other publications). Papers that merged pairs of references with a high chance of not being successfully combined were considered riskier than those that did not.

The team found that students’ risk-taking dispositions matched those of their supervisors. This link was stronger when students and their supervisors communicated frequently, and weaker when students were also mentored by scientists outside their lab.

Supervisors’ influence also persisted post-graduation. When the team analysed bibliometric data from 2,400 former PhD students and their supervisors, it found that a supervisors’ influence on their students’ approach to risk persisted a decade after leaving the lab — even if the former trainees changed research topics.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific finding that doctoral supervision influences long-term risk-taking behavior in research, which has broad implications for science policy and innovation culture. This insight can help shape training and funding policies to encourage impactful, risky research benefiting scientific progress and society.
articles.personality_title: PhD students inherit their supervisors’ taste for risky research
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Science often requires taking risks to make big discoveries. However, many researchers avoid risky projects because funding is harder to get for them. Until now, little was known about how doctoral supervisors influence their students’ willingness to take such risks.

**What happened** – A team of researchers studied over a thousand medical PhD students in Sweden and analyzed their supervisors’ and students’ publication records. They found that students tend to take similar risks in their research as their supervisors do. This connection was stronger when students communicated more with their supervisors. The influence remained strong even ten years after students finished their PhDs, even if they changed their research topics.

**Impact** – This study shows that the way supervisors encourage risk-taking shapes students’ long-term research choices. It suggests that training during doctoral education can be as important as funding policies for encouraging bold scientific ideas. Understanding this could help universities and policymakers support more innovative research.

**What's next step** – Future efforts might focus on how doctoral training programs can encourage healthy risk-taking. Universities could consider how supervisors mentor students to balance safety and innovation. Researchers may also explore how this influence works in other fields beyond medical science.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A PhD supervisor’s attitude toward risky research strongly shapes their students’ willingness to take risks, even years after graduation.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les doctorants héritent du goût du risque de leurs directeurs de thèse
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La science demande souvent de prendre des risques pour faire de grandes découvertes. Pourtant, beaucoup de chercheurs évitent les projets risqués parce qu’ils sont plus difficiles à financer. Jusqu’à présent, on savait peu comment les directeurs de thèse influencent la prise de risque chez leurs étudiants.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs ont étudié plus de mille doctorants en médecine en Suède et analysé les publications de leurs directeurs et des étudiants. Ils ont découvert que les étudiants prennent des risques similaires à ceux de leurs directeurs. Cette influence était plus forte quand les étudiants communiquaient beaucoup avec leur directeur. Elle restait forte même dix ans après la fin du doctorat, même si les étudiants changeaient de sujet de recherche.

**Impact** – Cette étude montre que la façon dont les directeurs encouragent la prise de risque influence les choix de recherche à long terme des étudiants. Cela suggère que la formation pendant le doctorat est aussi importante que les politiques de financement pour encourager des idées audacieuses. Comprendre cela peut aider les universités et les décideurs à soutenir plus de recherches innovantes.

**Prochaine étape** – Les futurs efforts pourraient se concentrer sur la manière dont les programmes de formation doctorale encouragent une prise de risque saine. Les universités pourraient réfléchir à la façon dont les directeurs encadrent les étudiants pour équilibrer sécurité et innovation. Les chercheurs pourraient aussi étudier cette influence dans d’autres domaines que la médecine.

**Phrase clé** – L’attitude d’un directeur de thèse face à la prise de risque influence fortement la volonté de ses étudiants de prendre des risques, même des années après leur diplôme.
articles.personality_title_es: Los doctorandos heredan el gusto por el riesgo de sus supervisores
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La ciencia suele requerir tomar riesgos para lograr grandes descubrimientos. Sin embargo, muchos investigadores evitan proyectos riesgosos porque es más difícil obtener financiamiento para ellos. Hasta ahora, se sabía poco sobre cómo los supervisores influyen en la disposición de sus estudiantes a asumir riesgos.

**Qué pasó** – Un equipo de investigadores estudió a más de mil estudiantes de doctorado en medicina en Suecia y analizó los registros de publicaciones de supervisores y estudiantes. Encontraron que los estudiantes tienden a tomar riesgos similares a los de sus supervisores. Esta conexión fue más fuerte cuando los estudiantes se comunicaban más con sus supervisores. La influencia se mantenía incluso diez años después de terminar el doctorado, aunque los estudiantes cambiaran de tema de investigación.

**Impacto** – Este estudio muestra que la forma en que los supervisores fomentan la toma de riesgos moldea las decisiones de investigación a largo plazo de los estudiantes. Sugiere que la formación durante el doctorado puede ser tan importante como las políticas de financiamiento para promover ideas científicas audaces. Entender esto puede ayudar a universidades y responsables políticos a apoyar investigaciones más innovadoras.

**Próximo paso** – En el futuro, se podría enfocar en cómo los programas de doctorado pueden fomentar una toma de riesgos saludable. Las universidades podrían considerar cómo los supervisores guían a los estudiantes para equilibrar la seguridad y la innovación. También se podría estudiar esta influencia en otras áreas más allá de la medicina.

**Frase clave** – La actitud de un supervisor de doctorado hacia el riesgo influye fuertemente en la disposición de sus estudiantes a asumir riesgos, incluso años después de graduarse.
